name: Kaitlyn Bui and Christina Tran
comment info: We noticed that the size of the square of the business corresponds with a business’ stock market value (i.e. the more money the stock market value has, the larger the square). We wondered if all the businesses that were shown in the diagram equal Apple’s stock market value. From quickly adding up the values of the other businesses shown in this graph, it seemed that they were close to the value of Apple’s stock market value, which is worth one trillion dollars. It is surprising to see that the stock values of Bank of America, Boeing, and Walt Disney only make up approximately 70% of Apple’s value. The story this graph is telling is that Apple is worth a trillion dollars, which is extensively much larger than most companies with the exception being Amazon. Our headline is “Apple Is Worth One Trillion. Bank of America Is Only ⅓ Of The Way There.”

name: Moderator Gina
comment info:
One trillion dollars not only has a lot of zeros (12!), but is equal to the sum of the stock values of 27 popular U. S. companies. It’s also the stock values of Apple and of Amazon in 2018. This graph gives you a picture of how big $1,000,000,000,000 is.

You noticed that the squares were of different sizes, but I wonder how these sizes were determined? Many of you wondered why some companies did not have stock market values. And did the colors mean anything?  You had some catchy headlines including TN of Chelsea’s “What Does a Trillion Mean?” and Jane of Milwaukee’s “Business By the Billions.” Good noticing and wondering leads to snappy headlines.

Thanks to all teachers and students who responded.  You can continue to post responses. Talk to your classmates and read the moderators’ replies. Dig deeper into what the graph shows.  Perhaps you will find more things to notice, wonder, claim or conjecture. Please check back on Thursday afternoon, September 27 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and two Stat Nuggets. And join us next Wednesday, October 3 for the next "What's Going On In This Graph?". I think it might possibly have to do with the Supreme Court.  Signing off – Sharon in Boston who has taught for about 630 million seconds and Gina Lee in Reston, Virginia who has taught for about 570 million seconds. Visit the "What's Going On In This Graph?" archives to keep responding. Hope to see you next week!

name: RE
comment info:
I notice that the title is 1,000,000 dollars and it talks about how Apple and Amazon's stock market value both surpassed a trillion dollars, but they don't include a box for those two companies. Also, I notice that there are different boxes with different companies, with some of the boxes including the number for their stock market value, with bigger boxes for higher stock market values. However, the smaller boxes don't have the number under the company name. 

I  wonder what the stock market values are for the other smaller boxes as well as why they didn't include Apple and Amazon. Is it because they already surpassed one trillion dollars? Also, what's the minimum stock value to be included on this graph?

"Catchy" headline: Companies that have yet to surpass a stock market value of one trillion dollars. In the graph, Apple and Amazon aren't shown, most likely because they have already surpassed a stock market value of a trillion dollars (which is the title of the graph) as stated in the caption. The companies in the biggest boxes, such as Bank of America, have the highest stock market value under one trillion dollars, which is $312 billion for Bank of America.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to “What’s Going On in This Graph?”.  Recently, a few American public corporations topped a stock market value of $1 trillion --  $1,000,000,000,000.   How big is that?  Study the graph and, from 9 am – 2 pm E.T., give us your responses online to these three questions. (On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.) 

	What do you NOTICE in this graph? 

	What do you WONDER? What are you curious about?

	What’s GOING ON in this graph? 

Write a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.  If your headline makes a claim, tell us what you noticed that supports your claim.

The questions are intended to build on one another, so try to answer them in order. Start with “I notice” and then “I wonder,” and end with the headline.

Then, read some responses. Click on "Reply" to an interesting response to get a discussion going. Learn different perspectives when you read what other students have to say about your response. 

We look forward to reading your discoveries.

name: Christophe Stevens
comment info: I notice that the sum of the market capitalizations of these companies  are roughly (if-not-exactly) equal to one trillion dollar, which was the market capitalization of Apple alone at the time of publication. I wonder why these companies were specifically selected, and if the selection process attempted to put apple market shares  in perspective to other industries. If this is the case, it would be interesting to compare with other companies within the  tech industry (i.e   Alphabet, Microsoft, Netflix as suggested above) .  The story this graph is telling us is that Apple and Oranges aren't the same thing.

name: Jane

My catchy headline would be: “Business by the Billions.”
